hypotaurium, ii, n., = u(potau/rion, the part of the body between the scrotum and fundament, Veg. Vet. 1, 46.

hypotēnūsa, ae, f., = u(potei/nousa, the hypothenuse, Hyg. de Limit. p. 176 Goes. Boëth. Art. Geom. p. 408, 20.—Hence, hy-potēnūsālis, e, adj., of or belonging to the hypothenuse, Boëth. Art. Geom. p. 412, 5 al.

hypothēca, ae, f., = u(poqh/kh, a pledge, security (esp. of immovable things; whereas pignus is used of movable things; cf. also: arra, arrabo),
a mortgage, Just. Inst. 4, 6, § 7; Dig. 13, 7, 9; 20, 1, 2 et saep. (in Cic. Fam. 13, 56, 2, written as Greek).—Hence, hypothēcārius, a, um, adj. hypotheca, of or relating to a mortgage: actio, Dig. 20, 4, 1 fin.: creditor, id. 42, 7, 1.
hypotheticus, i, m., = u(poqetiko/s, a mathematician who proceeds hypothetically, App. Dogm. Plat. 3 fin. p. 40.
hypotrăchēlium, ii, n., = u(potraxh/lion, in archit., the neck of a column below the capital, Vitr. 3, 2 sq.; 4, 3; 7.
hypotrimma, ătis, n., = u(po/trimma, a sauce made of all sorts of condiments, Apic. 1, 33, § 34.
Hypsa, ae, f., a river in Sicily, now Belici, Plin. 3, 8, 14, § 90; Sil. 14, 228.
Hypsaeus, i, m., a surname of P. Plautius, Cic. Att. 3, 8, 3.
Hypseus (dissyll.), ei, m., one who was present at the nuptials of Perseus, Ov. M. 5, 98.
Hypsicrătes, is, m., a grammarian, Gell. 16, 12.

Hypsipylē, ēs, f., = *(uyipu/lh, daughter of Thoas, queen of Lemnos in the time of the Argonauts; she saved her father when the women killed all the men; she also entertained Jason, Stat. Th. 4, 739 sq.; Ov. H. 6, 1 sq.; Val. Fl. 2, 90 sq.; Prop. 1, 15, 18: Hypsipyles patria, i. e.
Lemnos, Ov. M. 13, 399.—Hence, Hypsipylēus, a, um, adj.: tellus, i. e.
Lemnos, Ov. F. 3, 82.
hypsōma, ătis, n., = u(/ywma, height, Tert. ad Scap. 3.

Hyrcāni, ōrum, m., = *(/urkanoi, the Hyrcanians on the Caspian Sea, Mel. 1, 2, 5; 3, 5, 4; Plin. 6, 13, 15, § 36; Tac. A. 6, 36; 43; 11, 8; Cat. 11, 5; Sil. 13, 474 al. Macedones Hyrcani, the Hyrcanians intermixed with Macedonians in Lydia, Plin. 5, 29, 31, § 120; Tac. A. 2, 47.— Derivv. Hyrcānus, a, um, adj., of or belonging to the Hyrcanians, Hyrcanian: mare, i. e.
the Caspian Sea, Prop. 2, 30 (3, 28), 20: sinus, Mel. 3, 5, 3 sq.: montes, Plin. 31, 3, 26, § 43: luci, Val. Fl. 6, 114: canis, Lucr. 3, 750: tigres, Verg. A. 4, 367: campus, of the Macedones Hyrcani in Lydia, Liv. 37, 38.— Hyrcānius, a, um, adj., the same: mare, Plin. 6, 13, 15, § 36; 6, 16, 18, § 46; 5, 27, 27, § 97.—Subst.: Hyrcā-nia, ae, f., the country of the Hyrcanians, Hyrcania, Mel. 3, 5, 7.
Hyrgălētici campi, the Hyrgaletic plains, on the borders of Phrygia and Caria, Plin. 5, 29, 31, § 113.
Hyriē, ēs, f., = *(uri/h, a lake, and town situated by it, in Bœotia, Ov. M. 7, 271; 380; Plin. 4, 7, 12, § 26.

Hyrieus (trisyl.), ei, m., = *(urieu/s, a poor Bœotian, father of Orion, Ov. F. 5, 499; 535.—Hence, Hyriēŭs (quadrisyl.), a, um, adj.: Hyriēa proles, i. e.
Orion, Ov. F. 6, 719.
Hyrtăcus, i, m., father of Nisus, Verg. A. 9, 406.—Hence, Deriv.: Hyrtă-cides, i. e. Nisus, Verg. A. 9, 176 sq.; Ov. Ib. 631.
hysginum, i, n., = u(/sginon, the darkred color obtained from the plant u(/sgh, Plin. 9, 41, 65, § 140; 21, 26, 97, § 170; Vitr. 7, 14; Dig. 32, 1, 78, § 5.
hysōpītes (hysso-), ae, m., = u(sswpi/ths (oi)=nos), hyssop-wine, Plin. 14, 16, 19, § 109; Col. 12, 35.

hysōpum (hysso-), i, n., = u(/sswpos, hyssop: Hyssopus officinalis, Linn.; Plin. 25, 11, 87, § 136; 26, 11, 70, § 114; 26, 12, 76, § 124: asperges me hyssopo, et mundabor, Vulg. Psa. 50, 8 al.—And in a form corresp. to the Gr., hyssōpus, i, f., Cels. 4, 8; Col. 7, 5 fin.—Also scanned hysopum, Aemil. Mac. de Hyssopo.
Hystaspes, is or i, m., = *(usta/sphs, father of the Persian king Darius I., Plin. 6, 27, 31, § 133; Just. 1, 10, 6; Nep. Milt. 3; Reg. 1.
hystericus, a, um, adj., = u(steriko/s, hysterical, Mart. 11, 71, 1; 11, 7, 11.
hysterologia, ae, f., = u(sterologi/a, a rhet. fig., the hysteron proteron, Serv. ad Verg. A. 9, 816.
hystricōsus, a, um, adj. hystrix, prickly, thorny (late Lat.), trop.: hystricosae et lividae mentis homo, Hier. in. Ruf. 1, 7.
hystricŭlus, a, um, adj. id., prickly, hairy, bearded (post-class.): hystriculus, dasu/prwktos, Gloss. Philox.: pusio, Arn. 5, 174: puer, Tert. Pall. 4 dub. (al. striculus, ustriculus).
hystrix (histrix), icis, f., = u(/stric, a porcupine, Plin. 8, 35, 53, § 125; Calp. Ecl. 6, 14; Claud. Idyll. 4.
